newsitem.title: USA: School technology bonding proposed in Wisconsin.
newsitem.headline: School technology bonding proposed in Wisconsin.

text.p: Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction proposed an $87 million school technology bonding plan Friday as part of its fiscal 1998-99 budget recommendations.

Steven Dold, deputy state school superintendent, said the department wants to set up a bond-financed grant program through the state's educational technology board to finance technology and technology-related infrastructure programs at schools.

He said the program would total $87 million, representing expenditures of $100 per student in Wisconsin. The bonds would be issued by the state as part of its regular general obligation bonding program, Dold added.
He said a state-imposed cap placed on the amount school districts can raise each year has made it impossible for some districts to take advantage of technology.
"It creates inequities of opportunity," he added.
The cap the Wisconsin Legislature imposed three years ago restricts the amount districts can increase their budget each year to no more than $200 per student.
Dold said the technology bonding proposal was to be submitted to Gov. Tommy Thompson's office Friday as part of the department's budget request for the upcoming bienium.
